;随着加拿大迎来历史上最严重的野火季节，阴谋论开始流行网上声称环保主义者故意放火。

;

;“我敢打赌，全国肆虐的野火中有很大一部分是由绿色恐怖分子点燃的，他们希望为气候变化运动提供一点推动力，”马克西姆·伯尼尔 (Maxime Bernier) ，一位前外交部长出身的边缘党领袖，在 6 月 5 日的一条推文中说。

;

;到 2023 年为止，加拿大在这个季节的这个时候发生了比以往任何一年都大的野火，超过三场万公顷被烧毁。数万人因此疏散。

;

;在 TikTok 上，一段已经被观看了近 20,000 次的视频声称，新斯科舍省的火灾是“故意推动气候变化议程”。

; p>;

;一篇文章推测，由于艾伯塔省 90% 的火灾可能是“人为原因”，因此“生态恐怖分子”可能是幕后黑手。

;

;随着野火在魁北克蔓延，一些人质疑所有的大火怎么可能在同一天开始。一个点击量超过一百万的 Facebook 视频将火灾归咎于“恐怖袭击”。

;

;但该省森林消防局的 Karine Pelletier 表示，原因仍在调查中。

;

;“有很多是人为造成的，但这些几乎都是意外事故，”她说，并指出最近的雷击是魁北克许多野火的罪魁祸首。

;

;阿尔伯塔野火说，除非闪电涉及，大火被归类为人为引起的。这并不仅仅意味着纵火。

;

;加拿大野火笼罩美国东海岸的健康警报

;

;“这可能与一般原因有关，包括农业、林业、电力线或石油和天然气行业、铁路或住宅野火，”发言人 Melissa Story 说。

;

;新斯科舍省官员还表示，他们仍在调查该省火灾的起因，据推测这些火灾是人为引起的。< /p>;

;“人为引起的火灾可能是意外、故意或未确定的，”新斯科舍省消防局长办公室的女发言人希瑟·费尔贝恩 (Heather Fairbairn) 说。 “当然，我们看到气候变化的影响会增加火灾风险。”

;

;阴谋论者一再试图将毁灭性的野火季节归咎于出于政治动机的纵火犯。

;

;在澳大利亚的黑色2020 年夏天，社交媒体用户误导性地引用了前一年的纵火统计数据，将当季的丛林大火归咎于不相关的犯罪行为。

;

;2021 年在加利福尼亚州，纵火犯是多起野火的幕后黑手——但没有证据表明他们在推动正如一些人在网上声称的那样，这是一项气候变化议程。

;

;野火引发了 2.5 亿年前的“大灭绝”，中国研究证实

;

;Chris Russill，卡尔顿大学研究气候的教授改变沟通，说生态恐怖主义理论可能曾经有一些事实依据，但“后来它的重要性或重要性被夸大了”。

;

;加拿大就是这种情况，一些社交媒体用户引用对可疑火灾的真实报道，以编造关于不相关事件和地点的阴谋论。

;

;除了所谓的警惕主义之外，一些人错误地认为加拿大政府正在开始野火，要么是为了推进其气候变化政策，要么是为了迫使公民进入更容易实施“气候封锁”的城市。

;

;Russill 将这些担忧与加拿大签署 2015 年巴黎气候协定联系起来，该协定引发了对即将发生的气候危机的警报。

;

;随着自由党政府在过去十年实施更严格的气候上限和税收，Russill 表示，加拿大自然资源行业的人们已经变得具有防御性。

;

;“这种不满实际上并不总是与全球对阴暗的联合国的恐惧有关精英或生态义务警员，尽管这就是在这种叙述中被接受和孵化的方式，”他说。 “这表明与联邦政府和各省的关系变得更加牢固和有力。”

;

;社交媒体帖子坚称“纵火而非气候变化”是造成野火的原因，但自然资源部加拿大在 6 月 5 日告诉记者，炎热、干燥和多风的条件加剧了这个火灾季节。

;

;“气候变化正在增加野火的频率和强度，并造成更长的火灾季节，”主管迈克诺顿说加拿大林业中心将军。

;一名日本乘客因在中华航空公司的“辱骂”行为而受到抨击

;

;6 月 4 日，飞机舱门关闭后发生的事件导致从福冈飞往台北的航班起飞据台湾电视频道 TVBS 新闻周日晚间报道，航班延误了将近 40 分钟。

;

;在社交媒体上流传的一段视频中，可以看到这名乘客在对身边的两名女空姐讲话时变得越来越激动

;

;“你只会说中文吗？”她用英语问，并向服务员打手势。 “你在干什么？我是日本人。”

;

;韩国航空公司敦促机组人员在飞行中发生事故后脱掉裙子

;

;当服务员试图找借口回应机组人员的呼叫通知时，她继续在他们身后喊叫，促使其中一个人停下来转身照顾她。

;

;航班上的其他乘客也对她很生气。

;

;在另一个视频中，看到另一名乘客站在日本女子的座位前，在飞机即将起飞时要求她“闭嘴”。

;

;这名日本女子随后猛烈抨击另一名乘客

;

;有人还听到她问：“你们为什么不说日语？”

;

;其他视频片段显示她站在过道上，从座位上站起来，

;

;另一位机组人员试图安抚她。

;

;“我很难过，中华航空公司，”该女子喊道在一个剪辑中。 “你们在干什么？”

;

;在另一张照片中，她举起手臂好像想打机舱经理，然后用手指指着她。 “你必须先说对不起，”她喊道。

;

;还可以听到机舱经理要求日本女士就座，并用普通话冷静地向她发出多次法律警告。

;

;“国际法禁止你目前的行为，”客舱经理在一段视频中说。 “[我]再次警告你以下违规行为。”

;

;台湾航空公司中华航空公司向 TVBS 新闻证实，该女子最终被护送下飞机并移交给当地机场警察.

;

;日本航空公司为纯素食乘客提供香蕉和筷子作为飞机餐

;

;周一，一位名为“Marizmful”的 Twitter 用户挺身而出，声称她是视频中的女人。她解释说，她一直在“试图要 [一杯] 水并打电话给空乘人员”，但被​​忽略了。

;

;她补充说，她没有收到任何航班退款或保险赔付。下机并遭受“骚扰”。目前尚不清楚她指的是她在船上的经历还是网上的强烈反对。

;

;Twitter 用户（大多数是日本人）称这名乘客的行为“令人尴尬”，而且“非常不恰当和不可接受”。< /p>;

;甚至有人指责她“冒充日本人来侮辱日本”，指出Marizmful的日文推文存在许多拼写和语法错误。

;

;推文措辞笨拙，难以理解他们说，理解错误“即使是初中生也不会犯”。

;

;在一条推文中，Marizmful 批评空姐没有“向日本道歉或说谢谢”台湾网友附和。

;

;“你不值得任何道歉或感谢，”该网友写道。 “你的行为真是令人作呕。”

;

;周二，香港电视网凤凰卫视新闻发布了一段关于该事件的 TikTok 视频汇编，其中包括 Marizmful 的几条推文。

;

;截至周四，它已经获得了 100 万的浏览量、33,100 个赞和 3560 条评论。

;

;在微博上，#空姐未讲日语被日本女孩辱骂#或“空姐因不会说日语而被日本女性辱骂”的标签已被观看 2.2 亿次。

;

;TikTok 视频的最高评论感叹道：“卡伦斯是普遍的，”指的是一个贬义的俚语，指的是一个令人讨厌的、有权利的、通常是西方白人女性。

;

;还有人调侃“中华航空”乘客期待会说日语的空姐。

;中国一个离异父母的八岁男孩想念他的母亲一段他拿着睡衣在母亲公寓外等候的视频被发布到网上后，让许多社交媒体用户流下了眼泪。

;

;据白鹿视频报道，这名未透露姓名的男孩一直与父母离婚后，父亲和他的妹妹与他们的母亲在一起。孩子们有与父母双方的探视安排。

;

;刘姓母亲于 2018 年 1 月 10 日在中国西南部云南省昆明市的家中接男孩和妹妹一起过六一儿童节。 6月1日。

;

;一起度过了一天后，刘某带着儿子回了父亲家，自己则和妹妹逛了逛商店。

;

;然而，当他们回来的时候，却发现男孩坐在他们的前门，手里拿着他的睡衣。

;

;“他说他已经等了我一个多小时了，那天晚上他想睡在我家，”刘说。 “我的心为他而痛。没想到他会等我这么久。”

;

;小刘让男孩留下来和她一起睡在她的单人床上。

;

;此后，小刘取消了租了她的公寓，并在她前夫居住的同一个居民区租了一个地方，这样她就可以离儿子更近。

;

;“现在他可以随时见到他的妈妈。我会在附近看着他，陪着他，”刘说。

;

;这个男孩拿着睡衣的视频在本周早些时候被大陆媒体广泛报道后，在网上引发了强烈的情绪波动。

;

;一个人评论说：“懂事的孩子怕失去妈妈。”

;

;另一个人说：“我百感交集；我希望他的妈妈能成功，赚很多钱，这样她就可以毫无经济困难地照顾她的两个孩子。”

;

;“当我听到男孩说，‘我想和你一起睡’的那一刻，妈妈，我泪流满面。希望每一个天使般的孩子，都能被世界温柔对待。”第三人说。

;

;大陆社交媒体上经常出现关于孩子的感人故事。

;

;4月，一个故事关于中国东南部一名 7 岁女孩每天放学后去医院陪她生病的祖父的故事在网上疯传。

;

;去年，一名来自中国东部的 11 岁男孩成为了消息披露后，他每天早上都会花几个小时帮助父亲摆弄蛋糕和粥食品车。

; Fri, 09 Jun 2023 11:20:02 +0800 China envoy’s post-Soviet sovereignty faux pas shows why there’s no ‘freedom of speech’ in diplomacyhttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/opinion/article/3223374/china-envoys-post-soviet-sovereignty-faux-pas-shows-why-theres-no-freedom-speech-diplomacy?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.09 10:00;

;中国驻法国大使可能一直在努力摆脱困境他宣称他在最近质疑前苏联国家主权的有争议的评论中行使“言论自由”。

;

;但在地缘政治高度紧张的时候这样做是明智的，当强者正受到前所未有的审视，值得商榷。

;

;卢沙野的断言也提出了一个重要问题：如果外交官公开发表个人意见，如果这样做似乎与政府的官方立场相矛盾立场？

;

;我向三位外交官提出这个问题——两位来自亚洲，一位来自欧洲——他们的回答几乎相同。这三人都要求隐去他们的姓名。

;

;他们告诉我，外交官当然可以私下与朋友、家人和任何他们愿意的人分享他们的个人观点。但公开发表与政府官方路线不一致的意见是不允许的。

;

;“尤其是在 Facebook 或 Twitter 上，”一位外交官强调说。

;

;此类条款通常载于必须签署和遵守的行为准则或职业道德准则。

;

;该准则概述了外交官的职责和责任，很少公开，还包括行为标准和外交核心价值观

;

;中国特使质疑后苏联国家的主权引发了轩然大波

;

;与我交谈的一位亚洲外交官说，中国外交部“肯定”会有类似的代码，并大胆猜测它会比其他国家“更严格”。

;

;他举例说，根据他自己的观察，可能存在一条规则，规定“至少有两名外交官必须出席任何外交会议”。

;

;“大概是为了确保没有人说或做任何不合时宜的事情，”他说。

;

; p>;

;卢在 4 月份暗示苏联解体后出现的国家“根据国际法不具有有效地位，因为没有国际协议确认它们作为主权国家的地位”，这引发了轩然大波。

;

;他的评论似乎不仅指乌克兰，还指所有在 1991 年苏联解体后独立的前苏联共和国，包括欧盟成员国。

;

;为了为了遏制卢的言论引起的强烈抗议，尤其是在波罗的海国家，中国外交部发言人毛宁明确表示，北京尊重所有前苏联国家的“主权国家地位”。

;

;但在接受采访时法国媒体 Vu du Droit 上周周三表示，卢说他的评论的后果“不在于我是对还是错，而是在电视上公开辩论时是否有言论自由”。

;

;根据大使馆周六发布的采访记录，卢还强调应保障“言论自由”。

;

;中国驻法国特使猛烈抨击后苏联国家言论引发轩然大波后的“攻击”< /h3>;

;我发现“言论自由”与外交之间的联系不协调，主要是因为我发现在我的新闻职业生涯中与我打过交道的无数外交官在提供信息方面是最沉默寡言、最不坦率的.

;

;当然，除非他们被允许保持匿名或严格“不公开”——意思是“仅供您参考”而不是进一步传播，尤其是在媒体平台上。

;

;即使是“不公开”的评论也常常是稀疏的，或者是彻头彻尾的吝啬。虽然话虽如此，但这些外交官对于他们的爱好、冒险或隔壁邻居等各种话题的想法可能会非常慷慨。

;

;虽然外交官的坦率往往受到欢迎，但最好是媒体和国际社会不必猜测外交官在公共论坛上发表的哪些言论是“个人”言论，哪些代表其政府的言论。

;

;当前地缘政治环境复杂且足够具有挑战性，所以让我们从猜谜游戏中解脱出来。

;香港地铁公司将加大对滥用2港元（26美元）乘客的罚款美分）的长者交通补贴计划将于 6 月 25 日开始，当局将在全市范围内开展打击滥用行为的行动。

;

;行政长官李家超已责成政府部门调查滥用职权案件经济学家和立法者对该计划的财务可持续性提出了担忧。

;

;邮报详细介绍了您需要了解的有关票价计划的信息。

;

;补贴计划于 2012 年推出，当时香港特区行政长官曾荫权最初允许 65 岁及以上人士以及残疾人士每次乘坐指定公共交通工具支付港币 2 元，包括港铁、专营巴士、渡轮和专线小巴。

;

;香港地铁公司将对滥用 2 港元票价计划的行为处以罚款并采取严厉措施

;

;旨在通过鼓励符合条件的人更积极地参与社区活动，帮助建设一个充满关爱和包容的社会。< /p>;

;2022 年 2 月，时任行政长官林郑月娥领导的政府将年龄门槛降低至 60 岁，并将该计划扩大到红色小巴、前往离岛的渡轮服务和电车。付款是通过称为 JoyYou 卡的指定八达通卡完成的。

;

;公共交通运营商对于超过运营商自身提供的回扣的折扣票价由政府报销。该法案已从 2019-2020 财年的约 12.8 亿港元增加到 2022-23 财年的近 31 亿港元。明年符合条件的用户数量预计将达到 240 万。

;

;尽管政府的初衷是好的，但鉴于城市人口老龄化，此举引发了关于长期财务影响的争论。

;< p>;根据一份政府委托的咨询报告，将计划扩展至 60-64 岁年龄段将使成本在 2031 年达到 86 亿港元，占香港社会福利预算的 5.3%，而 2018 年为 1.6%。 2018.

;

;前交通部长张炳良早前指责上届政府将 60 至 64 岁的居民纳入计划“过于仓促”。他认为，虽然现在无法撤销此举，但当局应将优惠票价提高至 3 港元。

;

;行政会议召集人叶刘淑仪和其他成员陈健波也呼吁政府缩减补贴计划，担心它在财政上难以为继。

;

;长者八达通卡没有任何区别，任何人都可以在不提供身份或年龄证明的情况下购买八达通卡。 2019 年，香港发行了约 400 万张供 65 岁以上人士使用的八达通卡，尽管当年香港该年龄段的人口只有 132 万。

;

;但只有约 25,000 起怀疑虐待个案在 2020 年至 2022 年间检测到，其中 97% 在地铁站。

;

;;2023.06.09 09:00;
;;

;A China-led study has yielded the first observational evidence of the lives – and deaths – of the oldest stars in our universe.

;

;Scientists from China, Japan and Australia found the stars' unique chemical footprints in the halo of the Milky Way galaxy, using the combined power of two of the world's largest land-based telescopes.

;

;Their findings – from the Large Sky Area Multi-Object Fibre Spectroscopic Telescope (LAMOST) near Beijing and the Subaru Telescope in Hawaii – showed that so-called first-generation stars – which lit up the universe some 100-250 million years after the Big Bang – could be as colossal as 260 times the sun's mass.

;

;Their study, published in the journal Nature on Wednesday, also provided the first observation-based proof that the stars ended their lives in an unusual explosion, quite different from the supernovas we know today, and only predicted in theory until now.

;

;Harvard University theoretical physicist Avi Loeb, who was not involved in the research, hailed the discovery as “extremely important in confirming our theoretical ideas about the first generation of stars”.

;

;Loeb said first-generation stars are among the universe's biggest unsolved mysteries. Scientists predicted that they formed from pristine gas after the Big Bang and were made of just hydrogen and helium, without the heavier elements that were synthesised in the cores of later giant stars.

;

;Astronomy theory also suggested that these ancient bodies may have had masses equivalent to hundreds of suns and went through a unique partial explosion when they died.

;

;The first-generation stars were short-lived and very hard to detect, leaving only their chemical signatures in the next generation of stars.

;

;For their groundbreaking study, Zhao Gang from the National Astronomical Observatories of China and his colleagues sifted through the spectra of more than five million stars gathered by LAMOST.

;

;The information included chemical composition, temperature, brightness and other key properties which the scientists compared until they found a candidate, dubbed LAMOST J1010+2358.

;

;At about half the sun's mass, and some 3,300 light years away in the galactic halo, the star was extremely low in metals such as sodium and cobalt.

;

;The team compared the star's spectrum with theoretical models and concluded that it was most likely to have formed in a gas cloud dominated by the remnants of a first-generation star with a mass equivalent to 260 suns.

;

;Loeb explained that, unlike stellar explosions in the later universe – which occur as the star uses up its fuel and collapses into a neutron star or black hole – the explosion of LAMOST J1010+2358's parent star involved the generation of electrons and their antimatter counterpart positrons.

;

;The electron-positron pairs reduced the internal radiation pressure needed to support such a massive star against its own gravity. This led to a partial collapse, triggering a thermonuclear explosion that left nothing but a cloud of gas.

;

;Astronomers had also predicted that this process would result in a big difference in the abundance of ions with odd and even charge numbers – like sodium/magnesium and cobalt/nickel, Loeb said.

;

;Chinese astronomy satellite finds strongest magnetic field in the universe

;

;And this was exactly what the researchers observed with LAMOST and Subaru – “a pronounced odd-even effect” as the paper's co-author Xing Qianfan put it.

;

;In a press release on Wednesday, Zhao said there was no direct evidence of supernova explosions of such massive, metal-poor stars before this study.

;

;“Hopefully, our work will have a positive impact on the study of the origin of elements, star formation in the early universe, and the chemical evolution of galaxies,” he said.

;

;Black hole image captures imagination and prompts new vision for China

;

;Zhao said the team intends to continue the search for stars with unusual chemical compositions, to help better understand how first-generation stars were formed, both within and outside the Milky Way.

;

;They plan to combine LAMOST's power with the Xuntian space telescope, a Hubble-class device that could launch later next year.

;

;The Chinese co-orbiting optical space telescope module will have a field of view more than 300 times greater than the Hubble. Its wide field of view will allow Xuntian to map up to 40 per cent of the sky over 10 years, using a huge 2.5 billion pixel camera.

Hong Kong internet providers express concerns over enforcing possible protest song banhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3223452/blocking-google-hong-kong-internet-providers-express-concerns-over-enforcing-possible-protest-song?utm_source=rss_feed

;Hong Kong-based internet service providers (ISPs) have expressed fears that the burden of enforcing a potential ban on a protest song sought by the government will fall on them, while legal experts say foreign tech giants such as Google are unlikely to comply with the pending injunction.

;

;Residents in the city could be cut off from Google altogether if providers were obliged to block “Glory to Hong Kong”, an industry group said.

;

;In an unprecedented move, Secretary for Justice Paul Lam Ting-kwok on Monday filed an application to the High Court for an injunction over the tune, which is regarded as the unofficial anthem of the 2019 anti-government protests against a now-shelved extradition bill.

;

;The writ asked the court to restrain people harbouring criminal intent from “broadcasting, performing, printing, publishing, selling, offering for sale, distributing, disseminating, displaying or reproducing” the song “in any way”.

;

;The government said it aimed to target anyone who intended to incite others to separate Hong Kong from the country, or insult the national anthem “March of the Volunteers” by disseminating the protest song, according to an earlier statement.

;

;“Glory to Hong Kong”, instead of the Chinese national anthem, has appeared among the top Google search results for “Hong Kong national anthem”. The issue came to light late last year after a series of mix-ups at international sporting tournaments.

;

;Hong Kong must get Google to fix national anthem results problem: sports body

;

;According to Craig Choy Ki, a barrister in the United States, there could be several reasons Google and other US-based companies would ignore an order granted by a Hong Kong court.

;

;The injunction's aim could be technically infeasible to achieve or tech firms might decline requests based on corporate values such as protection of free speech, he said.

;

;He added that the companies also faced the prospect of being grilled in the US Congress.

;

;'Glory to Hong Kong' protest song to be banned? Government files court injunction

;

;“US firms do not only face a business environment,” he said. “Among their political considerations is whether to risk having their CEOs explain to the US Congress why they chose to cater to a request made by [the authorities of] such a small market.”

;

;China has been a bipartisan target on Capitol Hill, with the most recent example being a letter sent by Democratic and Republican lawmakers on Wednesday urging the State Department to bar Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu from visiting San Francisco in November for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit.

;

;Lento Yip Yuk-fai, chairman of the Hong Kong Internet Service Providers Association, expressed concerns over the prospect of Google sidestepping the injunction.

;

;The order, if granted, would also bar anyone from “assisting”, “causing”, “aiding” or “knowingly allowing” others to commit or participate in the specified acts in relation to disseminating the protest song.

;

;Yip said the mention of “assisting” drew his attention.

;

;Google's anthem results for Hong Kong have improved after optimisation: Sun Dong

;

;Since the national security law took effect nearly three years ago, ISPs in Hong Kong have been asked by law enforcement to block local users' access to certain websites, including one that published information related to the 2019 social unrest.

;

;Yip said network providers in Hong Kong could block access to an entire site based on IP addresses, but they were not technically able to see what internet users were looking at on search engines and streaming platforms because the data flow was encrypted.

;

;“It's technically impossible to rely on ISPs to identify and block specific content. Even mainland China's Great Firewall can't do it,” he said. “We can't maintain access to a website where some content is visible to users and other content isn't.”

;

;If enforcing the song ban became the responsibility of ISPs based in Hong Kong, internet users might lose access to some or all Google services because providers might have to block access to IP addresses under the website to ensure full compliance, he said.

;

;“Blocking Google will have a great impact on Hong Kong. Can ISPs be spared from bearing the consequences?” he said.

;

;Hong Kong-based lawyer Joshua Chu Kiu-wah, who focuses on technology law, agreed that it was possible ISPs could also be required to comply with the injunction, details of which he maintained would be subject to the court's discretion.

;

;The Hong Kong courts might have jurisdiction over content accessible from the city, but Chu said it would be difficult to enforce an injunction against content hosted on servers based elsewhere by overseas entities.

;

;How anthem blunders are being tackled after Hong Kong rugby was left reeling

;

;“It's one thing to obtain the injunction, if granted. Effectiveness of the order, on the other hand, is another subject altogether and will largely depend on whether the advocate in question sufficiently assists the court in spelling out the correct terms of the order that will enable easy implementation and enforcement,” he said.

;

;The protest song can also be found on various streaming and social media platforms, including Facebook, Spotify and Apple Music. Different versions of the tune have topped the Hong Kong chart on iTunes after the government announced it was seeking the court order.

;

;'Ill management' by Hong Kong ice hockey group caused anthem mix-up: sports body

;

;Both Google and Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram, refused to comment. The Post has also approached Apple and Spotify for a response.

;

;George Chen Shu, former head of public policy for Greater China at Meta, said the injunction would increase compliance costs and complexity for tech giants to remain in the city.

;

;“If [companies] choose to ignore [the pending order], they could face legal consequences, otherwise the government will lose face if platforms don't comply and the government doesn't take further action,” Chen added.

;

;The High Court will hear the government's application next Monday.
